--- title: "Chap9: IV" author: "Anthony El Khoueiry" format: html: code-line-numbers: true df-print: paged --- ---- ::: {.cell hash='09_iv_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-1_7655c88ec236048e4367f946151e5d6b'} ```{.r .cell-code} # Libraries library(tidyverse) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr} ``` #> ── Attaching core tidyverse packages ──────────────────────── tidyverse 2.0.0 ── #> ✔ dplyr 1.1.4 ✔ readr 2.1.4 #> ✔ forcats 1.0.0 ✔ stringr 1.5.1 #> ✔ ggplot2 3.4.4 ✔ tibble 3.2.1 #> ✔ lubridate 1.9.3 ✔ tidyr 1.3.0 #> ✔ purrr 1.0.2 #> ── Conflicts ────────────────────────────────────────── tidyverse_conflicts() ── #> ✖ dplyr::filter() masks stats::filter() #> ✖ dplyr::lag() masks stats::lag() #> ℹ Use the conflicted package () to force all conflicts to become errors ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} library(dagitty) library(ggdag) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr} ``` #> #> Attaching package: 'ggdag' #> #> The following object is masked from 'package:stats': #> #> filter ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} library(estimatr) library(AER) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr} ``` #> Loading required package: car #> Loading required package: carData #> #> Attaching package: 'car' #> #> The following object is masked from 'package:dplyr': #> #> recode #> #> The following object is masked from 'package:purrr': #> #> some #> #> Loading required package: lmtest #> Loading required package: zoo #> #> Attaching package: 'zoo' #> #> The following objects are masked from 'package:base': #> #> as.Date, as.Date.numeric #> #> Loading required package: sandwich #> Loading required package: survival ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} #1 # Definition of the DAG dag <- dagify( spentTime ~ featureUsed, spentTime ~ Unobserved, featureUsed ~ Unobserved, featureUsed ~ encourgement, exposure = "featureUsed", latent = "Unobserved", outcome = "spentTime", coords = list(x = c(Unobserved = 1, featureUsed = 0, spentTime = 2, encourgement = -1), y = c(Unobserved = 1, featureUsed = 0, spentTime = 0, encourgement = 0)), labels = c( "spentTime" = "Time Spent on the App", "featureUsed" = "The new feature is used", "encourgement" = "User encourgement to use feature", "Unobserved" = "Unobserved variables" ) ) # Plot DAG ggdag(dag, text = FALSE, use_labels = "label") ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](09_iv_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-1-1.png){width=672} ::: ```{.r .cell-code} ######################################################## # Load the data df <- readRDS('C:/Users/user/OneDrive/Desktop/UNI/TUHH/SEM 3/CAUSAL DATA SC/RDS/rand_enc.rds') # Explore the data head(df) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} `````{=html}
````` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} # 2 # Naive Estimate naive_estimate <- lm(time_spent ~ used_ftr, data = df) summary(naive_estimate) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` #> #> Call: #> lm(formula = time_spent ~ used_ftr, data = df) #> #> Residuals: #> Min 1Q Median 3Q Max #> -20.4950 -3.5393 0.0158 3.5961 20.5051 #> #> Coefficients: #> Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|) #> (Intercept) 18.86993 0.06955 271.3 <2e-16 *** #> used_ftr 10.82269 0.10888 99.4 <2e-16 *** #> --- #> Signif. codes: 0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1 #> #> Residual standard error: 5.351 on 9998 degrees of freedom #> Multiple R-squared: 0.497, Adjusted R-squared: 0.497 #> F-statistic: 9881 on 1 and 9998 DF, p-value: < 2.2e-16 ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} ######################################################## # 3 # The correlation matrix cor(df) %>% round(2) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` #> rand_enc used_ftr time_spent #> rand_enc 1.00 0.20 0.13 #> used_ftr 0.20 1.00 0.71 #> time_spent 0.13 0.71 1.00 ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} cat(" ## Since the naive estimate (10.82269) is greater than the IV robust estimate using rand_enc as ## an instrument (9.738175), we would consider the naive estimate to have an upward bias. This ## implies that the naive estimate overestimates the effect of used_ftr on time_spent.") ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` #> ## Since the naive estimate (10.82269) is greater than the IV robust estimate using rand_enc as #> ## an instrument (9.738175), we would consider the naive estimate to have an upward bias. This #> ## implies that the naive estimate overestimates the effect of used_ftr on time_spent. ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} cat("## A strong correlation between used_ftr and time_spent can be seen.") ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` #> ## A strong correlation between used_ftr and time_spent can be seen. ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} cat(" ## Assuming rand_enc as an Instrumental variable would make sense because ## it has a weak correlation with the outcome (time_spent) and a stronger ## one with the treatment (used_ftr).") ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` #> ## Assuming rand_enc as an Instrumental variable would make sense because #> ## it has a weak correlation with the outcome (time_spent) and a stronger #> ## one with the treatment (used_ftr). ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} cat("## While the correlation between the instrumental variable and outcome is not ## zero (maybe due to noise), this correlation is relatively low.") ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` #> ## While the correlation between the instrumental variable and outcome is not #> ## zero (maybe due to noise), this correlation is relatively low. ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} ######################################################## # 4 # Instrumental Variable Estimation with rand_enc and robust standard errors model_iv_robust <- iv_robust(time_spent ~ used_ftr | rand_enc, data = df) summary(model_iv_robust) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` #> #> Call: #> iv_robust(formula = time_spent ~ used_ftr | rand_enc, data = df) #> #> Standard error type: HC2 #> #> Coefficients: #> Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|) CI Lower CI Upper DF #> (Intercept) 19.312 0.2248 85.89 0.000e+00 18.872 19.75 9998 #> used_ftr 9.738 0.5353 18.19 8.716e-73 8.689 10.79 9998 #> #> Multiple R-squared: 0.4921 , Adjusted R-squared: 0.492 #> F-statistic: 331 on 1 and 9998 DF, p-value: < 2.2e-16 ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} ## Hansen J test #Residuals and fitted values from the model residuals_iv <- residuals(model_iv_robust) fitted_values_iv <- fitted(model_iv_robust) # Perform Hansen J test hansen_test_stat <- sum(residuals_iv * fitted_values_iv) p_value_hansen <- 1 - pchisq(hansen_test_stat, df = 1) # Results cat("Hansen J Test Statistic:", hansen_test_stat, "\n") ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` #> Hansen J Test Statistic: 0 ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} cat("P-value:", p_value_hansen, "\n") ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` #> P-value: 1 ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} cat(" ## Hansen J test with a test statistic close to 0 and a p-value close to 1 indicates ## that the instrument used in the model is not violating the over-identifying ## restrictions. In other words, the instrument is valid for the model, and there is ## no evidence to suggest that the instrument is endogenous or correlated with the error term.") ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` #> ## Hansen J test with a test statistic close to 0 and a p-value close to 1 indicates #> ## that the instrument used in the model is not violating the over-identifying #> ## restrictions. In other words, the instrument is valid for the model, and there is #> ## no evidence to suggest that the instrument is endogenous or correlated with the error term. ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} cat("Naive Estimate:", coef(naive_estimate)['used_ftr'], "\n") ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` #> Naive Estimate: 10.82269 ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} cat("IV Robust Estimate (rand_enc):", model_iv_robust$coefficients['used_ftr'], "\n") ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` #> IV Robust Estimate (rand_enc): 9.738175 ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} cat(" ## Since the naive estimate (10.82269) is greater than the IV robust estimate using rand_enc as ## an instrument (9.738175), we would consider the naive estimate to have an upward bias. This ## implies that the naive estimate overestimates the effect of used_ftr on time_spent.") ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` #> ## Since the naive estimate (10.82269) is greater than the IV robust estimate using rand_enc as #> ## an instrument (9.738175), we would consider the naive estimate to have an upward bias. This #> ## implies that the naive estimate overestimates the effect of used_ftr on time_spent. ``` ::: :::
